item.title: Caterpillars of the US north-east
item.trailText: Since he was a boy, New England-based naturalist and photographer Samuel Jaffe has been fascinated by caterpillars. From 2008, he has been photographing as many different local types as he can, capturing the survival techniques and defensive adaptations of these remarkable and beautiful creatures.
item.standFirst:
Since he was a boy, New England-based naturalist and photographer Samuel Jaffe has been fascinated by caterpillars. From 2008, he has been photographing as many different local types as he can, capturing the survival techniques and defensive adaptations of these remarkable and beautiful creatures.

His work and passion has resulted in the Caterpillar Lab, an educational, non-profit organisation promoting the diversity of caterpillars of the American north east.

An exhibition of his work, Life on a Leaf Edge, is taking place at Franklin Park Conservatory in Columbus, Ohio, until 27 September, 2015

cards.title: Festival feeling / Extreme emotions and the face in the crowd
cards.rawTitle: Extreme emotions and the face in the crowd

item.title: Festival feeling: extreme emotions and the face in the crowd
item.trailText: Across five years, five countries and 11 music festivals, Australian photographer Nic Bezzina has documented one constant – the raw emotion expressed by festival-goers
item.standFirst: Across five years, five countries and 11 music festivals, Australian photographer Nic Bezzina has documented one constant – the raw emotion expressed by festival-goers. As Bezzina crowdfunds for his latest book, Release the Crowd, we pick a selection of his best festival photographs from around the world

displayImages.caption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2012
‘It was the passion and energy of the front line that got me excited about photographing festival crowds,’ says Nic Bezzina. All photographs: Nic Bezzina.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2012
‘It was the passion and energy of the front line that got me excited about photographing festival crowds,’ says Nic Bezzina. All photographs: Nic Bezzina.

displayImages.caption:
Hellfest, France, 2014
‘I never ask subjects to pose. It’s about being in the right place at the right time. Here’s a young man at Hellfest, ready for battle in the middle of the mosh pit.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Hellfest, France, 2014
‘I never ask subjects to pose. It’s about being in the right place at the right time. Here’s a young man at Hellfest, ready for battle in the middle of the mosh pit.’

displayImages.caption:
Hellfest, France, 2014
‘At times at Hellfest, you could barely see 10 feet in front of you and you could taste the dust in your mouth here. I both loved and hated that dust.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Hellfest, France, 2014
‘At times at Hellfest, you could barely see 10 feet in front of you and you could taste the dust in your mouth here. I both loved and hated that dust.’

displayImages.caption:
Future Music, Sydney, 2013
‘I took this from the party stage at Future Music festival. It’s all beats and bright sunlight.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Future Music, Sydney, 2013
‘I took this from the party stage at Future Music festival. It’s all beats and bright sunlight.’

displayImages.caption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2012
‘Here at Soundwave, American goth-metal band Coal Chamber had just started playing their most recognised song Loco – the crowd went crazy.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2012
‘Here at Soundwave, American goth-metal band Coal Chamber had just started playing their most recognised song Loco – the crowd went crazy.’

displayImages.caption:
Wacken Open Air, Germany, 2014
‘The Wasteland Warriors are a group of artists and performers who are a staple of Wacken in Germany. They’re great to photograph.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Wacken Open Air, Germany, 2014
‘The Wasteland Warriors are a group of artists and performers who are a staple of Wacken in Germany. They’re great to photograph.’

displayImages.caption:
Bloodstock, UK, 2014
 ‘Black metal band Emperor were headlining Bloodstock the night this was taken. This brought out lots of amazing outfits and corpse paint.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Bloodstock, UK, 2014
 ‘Black metal band Emperor were headlining Bloodstock the night this was taken. This brought out lots of amazing outfits and corpse paint.’

displayImages.caption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2015
‘Sometimes you see crazy things in the moshpit, which is what keeps drawing me back in.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Soundwave, Sydney, 2015
‘Sometimes you see crazy things in the moshpit, which is what keeps drawing me back in.’

displayImages.caption:
Download, UK, 2013
 ‘I was watching a band when I noticed this girl next to me – I pointed my camera up from my hip and fired a few shots as she turned around.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Download, UK, 2013
 ‘I was watching a band when I noticed this girl next to me – I pointed my camera up from my hip and fired a few shots as she turned around.’

displayImages.caption:
Soundwave, Melbourne, 2014
‘When American heavy metal band Gwar sprayed the Melbourne crowd in litres of fake blood, I caught this “messiah” and his intense gaze’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Soundwave, Melbourne, 2014
‘When American heavy metal band Gwar sprayed the Melbourne crowd in litres of fake blood, I caught this “messiah” and his intense gaze’

displayImages.caption:
Sonisphere, UK, 2014
‘Here, Metallica had just taken to the stage, the last band on the last night of a three-day festival.’
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Sonisphere, UK, 2014
‘Here, Metallica had just taken to the stage, the last band on the last night of a three-day festival.’

item.title: Vintage newsreel of London tube strikes - archive video
item.trailText: From the 1950s through to present day, we look back at vintage news broadcasts of transport strikes in London
item.standFirst: From the 1950s through to present day, we look back at vintage news broadcasts of transport strikes in London. Thursday's 24-hour tube strike, in which more than 20,000 workers walked off their jobs, was the largest in 13 years, but by no means the first time Londoners had to leg it to work

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Tube strikes through the decades - archive newsreel  Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: Tour de France / Day six highlights

item.title: Tour de France: day six highlights
item.trailText: Day six saw another big crash, this time involving yellow jersey-wearer Tony Martin
item.standFirst: Day 6, saw another big crash, this time involving the yellow jersey-wearer Tony Martin. The stage was won by Martin's team mate Zdenek Stybar in an uphill sprint in Le Havre. Daniel Teklehaimanot made history on Thursday by becoming the first African rider to claim a major jersey, the King of the Mountains. Chris Froome maintained his lead over his main rivals.

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Tour De France day 6 highlights Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: A cook's books / A blogger's recipes inspired by literature
cards.rawTitle: A blogger's recipes inspired by literature

item.title: Cook's books: a blogger's recipes inspired by literature
item.trailText: Kate Young makes recipes for her virtual Little Library Cafe, reimagining meals from her favourite fiction and writing about the significance that each book has in her life. Here she picks a selection of her recipes, with quotes from the books
item.standFirst:
Kate Young makes recipes for her virtual Little Library Cafe, reimagining meals from her favourite fiction and writing about the significance each book has in her life. Here she picks a selection of her recipes, with quotes from the books. You can also follow her on Instagram at @bakingfiction

  • What are your favourite literary meals? Have you been inspired to try them? Let us know in the comments

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Crab, Avocado and Mayonnaise.
Book: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath (1966).
Scene: “I had a vision of the celestially white kitchens of Ladies’ Day stretching into infinity. I saw avocado pear after avocado pear being stuffed with crabmeat and mayonnaise under brilliant lights. I saw the delicate, pink-mottled claw meat poking seductively through its blanket of mayonnaise and the bland yellow pear cup with its rim of alligator-green cradling the whole mess.
Poison.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Crab, Avocado and Mayonnaise.
Book: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath (1966).
Scene: “I had a vision of the celestially white kitchens of Ladies’ Day stretching into infinity. I saw avocado pear after avocado pear being stuffed with crabmeat and mayonnaise under brilliant lights. I saw the delicate, pink-mottled claw meat poking seductively through its blanket of mayonnaise and the bland yellow pear cup with its rim of alligator-green cradling the whole mess.
Poison.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Salted Caramel Brownies.
Book: A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole (1980).
Scene: “‘Mother, are you making a scene?’ Ignatius asked irritably. ‘Can’t you see that Miss Darlene and I are speaking? You have some cakes with you. Eat those. You’re always complaining that you never go anywhere. I would have imagined that you would be enjoying your night on the town.’
Ignatius was back on radar, so Mrs Reilly reached in her boxes and ate a brownie.
‘Like one?‘ she asked the bartender. ‘They nice.’”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Salted Caramel Brownies.
Book: A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole (1980).
Scene: “‘Mother, are you making a scene?’ Ignatius asked irritably. ‘Can’t you see that Miss Darlene and I are speaking? You have some cakes with you. Eat those. You’re always complaining that you never go anywhere. I would have imagined that you would be enjoying your night on the town.’
Ignatius was back on radar, so Mrs Reilly reached in her boxes and ate a brownie.
‘Like one?‘ she asked the bartender. ‘They nice.’”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Fried Chicken and Rolls.
Book: To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee (1960).
Scene: “‘Gracious alive, Cal, what’s all this?’ He was staring at his breakfast plate.
Calpurnia said, ‘Tom Robinson’s daddy sent you along this chicken this morning. I fixed it.’
‘You tell him I’m proud to get it – bet they don’t have chicken for breakfast at the White House. What are these?’
‘Rolls,’ said Calpurnia. ‘Estelle down at the hotel sent ‘em.’”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Fried Chicken and Rolls.
Book: To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee (1960).
Scene: “‘Gracious alive, Cal, what’s all this?’ He was staring at his breakfast plate.
Calpurnia said, ‘Tom Robinson’s daddy sent you along this chicken this morning. I fixed it.’
‘You tell him I’m proud to get it – bet they don’t have chicken for breakfast at the White House. What are these?’
‘Rolls,’ said Calpurnia. ‘Estelle down at the hotel sent ‘em.’”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Dumplings.
Book: The Kitchen God’s Wife by Amy Tan (1992).
Scene: “Back home, I told the cook girl to boil enough pots of water and to chop enough pork and vegetables to make a thousand dumplings, both steamed and boiled, with plenty of fresh ginger, good soy sauce, and sweet vinegar for dipping. Hulan helped me knead the flour and roll out the dough into small circles.
I admit I was at first impressed by her cooking skills.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Dumplings.
Book: The Kitchen God’s Wife by Amy Tan (1992).
Scene: “Back home, I told the cook girl to boil enough pots of water and to chop enough pork and vegetables to make a thousand dumplings, both steamed and boiled, with plenty of fresh ginger, good soy sauce, and sweet vinegar for dipping. Hulan helped me knead the flour and roll out the dough into small circles.
I admit I was at first impressed by her cooking skills.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Christmas Pudding.
Book: Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone by JK Rowling (1997).
Scene: “Flaming Christmas puddings followed the turkey. Percy nearly broke his teeth on a silver sickle embedded in his slice. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder and redder in the face as he called for more wine, finally kissing Professor McGonagall on the cheek, who, to Harry’s amazement, giggled and blushed, her top hat lopsided.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Christmas Pudding.
Book: Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone by JK Rowling (1997).
Scene: “Flaming Christmas puddings followed the turkey. Percy nearly broke his teeth on a silver sickle embedded in his slice. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder and redder in the face as he called for more wine, finally kissing Professor McGonagall on the cheek, who, to Harry’s amazement, giggled and blushed, her top hat lopsided.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Key Lime Pie.
Book: Heartburn by Nora Ephron (1983).
Scene: “If I had to do it all over again, I would have made a different pie. The pie I threw at Mark made a terrific mess, but a blueberry pie would have been even better, since it would have permanently ruined his new blazer, the one he bought with Thelma. But Betty said to bring a Key lime pie, so I did.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Key Lime Pie.
Book: Heartburn by Nora Ephron (1983).
Scene: “If I had to do it all over again, I would have made a different pie. The pie I threw at Mark made a terrific mess, but a blueberry pie would have been even better, since it would have permanently ruined his new blazer, the one he bought with Thelma. But Betty said to bring a Key lime pie, so I did.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Sticky Ginger Cake.
Book: Five on a Treasure Island by Enid Blyton (1942).
Scene: “It wasn’t long before all four were sitting down to a good tea. Aunt Fanny had baked new scones for them, and had made a ginger cake with black treacle. It was dark brown and sticky to eat. The children finished it all up and said it was the nicest they had ever tasted.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Sticky Ginger Cake.
Book: Five on a Treasure Island by Enid Blyton (1942).
Scene: “It wasn’t long before all four were sitting down to a good tea. Aunt Fanny had baked new scones for them, and had made a ginger cake with black treacle. It was dark brown and sticky to eat. The children finished it all up and said it was the nicest they had ever tasted.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Marmalade Roll.
Book: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis (1950)
Scene: “And when they had finished the fish, Mrs Beaver brought unexpectedly out of the oven a great and gloriously sticky marmalade roll, steaming hot, and at the same time moved the kettle onto the fire, so that when they had finished the marmalade roll the tea was made and ready to be poured out.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Marmalade Roll.
Book: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis (1950)
Scene: “And when they had finished the fish, Mrs Beaver brought unexpectedly out of the oven a great and gloriously sticky marmalade roll, steaming hot, and at the same time moved the kettle onto the fire, so that when they had finished the marmalade roll the tea was made and ready to be poured out.”
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight.
Book: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl (1964).
Scene: “‘Why not?’ the fat shopkeeper said, reaching behind him again and taking another Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight from the shelf. He laid it on the counter. Charlie picked it up and tore off the wrapper … and suddenly … from underneath the wrapper … there came a brilliant flash of gold. Charlie’s heart stood still.’
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight.
Book: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl (1964).
Scene: “‘Why not?’ the fat shopkeeper said, reaching behind him again and taking another Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight from the shelf. He laid it on the counter. Charlie picked it up and tore off the wrapper … and suddenly … from underneath the wrapper … there came a brilliant flash of gold. Charlie’s heart stood still.’
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Blueberry and Chocolate Pancakes.
Book: The Goldfinch by Donna Tartt (2013).
Scene: “This wasn’t what I’d been expecting them to ask. The truth was: we hadn’t eaten breakfast at all that morning because I was in trouble at school and my mother was mad at me, but I was too embarrassed to say that.
‘You don’t remember?’
‘Pancakes,’ I burst out desperately.
‘Oh yeah?’ Ray looked at me shrewdly. ‘Your mother make them?’
‘Yes.’
‘What’d she put in them? Blueberries, chocolate chips?’
I nodded.
‘Both?’
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Blueberry and Chocolate Pancakes.
Book: The Goldfinch by Donna Tartt (2013).
Scene: “This wasn’t what I’d been expecting them to ask. The truth was: we hadn’t eaten breakfast at all that morning because I was in trouble at school and my mother was mad at me, but I was too embarrassed to say that.
‘You don’t remember?’
‘Pancakes,’ I burst out desperately.
‘Oh yeah?’ Ray looked at me shrewdly. ‘Your mother make them?’
‘Yes.’
‘What’d she put in them? Blueberries, chocolate chips?’
I nodded.
‘Both?’
Recipe here.

displayImages.caption:
Meal: Muffins.
Book: A Little Princess by Frances Hodgson Burnett (1905).
Scene: “Imagine, if you can, what the rest of the evening was like. How they crouched by the fire which blazed and leaped and made so much of itself in the little grate. How they removed the covers of the dishes, and found rich, hot, savory soup, which was a meal in itself, and sandwiches and toast and muffins enough for both of them. The mug from the washstand was used as Becky’s tea cup, and the tea was so delicious that it was not necessary to pretend that it was anything but tea.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meal: Muffins.
Book: A Little Princess by Frances Hodgson Burnett (1905).
Scene: “Imagine, if you can, what the rest of the evening was like. How they crouched by the fire which blazed and leaped and made so much of itself in the little grate. How they removed the covers of the dishes, and found rich, hot, savory soup, which was a meal in itself, and sandwiches and toast and muffins enough for both of them. The mug from the washstand was used as Becky’s tea cup, and the tea was so delicious that it was not necessary to pretend that it was anything but tea.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Crab, Avocado and Mayonnaise.
Book: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath (1966).
Scene: “I had a vision of the celestially white kitchens of Ladies’ Day stretching into infinity. I saw avocado pear after avocado pear being stuffed with crabmeat and mayonnaise under brilliant lights. I saw the delicate, pink-mottled claw meat poking seductively through its blanket of mayonnaise and the bland yellow pear cup with its rim of alligator-green cradling the whole mess.
Poison.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Crab, Avocado and Mayonnaise.
Book: The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath (1966).
Scene: “I had a vision of the celestially white kitchens of Ladies’ Day stretching into infinity. I saw avocado pear after avocado pear being stuffed with crabmeat and mayonnaise under brilliant lights. I saw the delicate, pink-mottled claw meat poking seductively through its blanket of mayonnaise and the bland yellow pear cup with its rim of alligator-green cradling the whole mess.
Poison.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Salted Caramel Brownies.
Book: A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole (1980).
Scene: “‘Mother, are you making a scene?’ Ignatius asked irritably. ‘Can’t you see that Miss Darlene and I are speaking? You have some cakes with you. Eat those. You’re always complaining that you never go anywhere. I would have imagined that you would be enjoying your night on the town.’
Ignatius was back on radar, so Mrs Reilly reached in her boxes and ate a brownie.
‘Like one?‘ she asked the bartender. ‘They nice.’”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Salted Caramel Brownies.
Book: A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole (1980).
Scene: “‘Mother, are you making a scene?’ Ignatius asked irritably. ‘Can’t you see that Miss Darlene and I are speaking? You have some cakes with you. Eat those. You’re always complaining that you never go anywhere. I would have imagined that you would be enjoying your night on the town.’
Ignatius was back on radar, so Mrs Reilly reached in her boxes and ate a brownie.
‘Like one?‘ she asked the bartender. ‘They nice.’”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Fried Chicken and Rolls.
Book: To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee (1960).
Scene: “‘Gracious alive, Cal, what’s all this?’ He was staring at his breakfast plate.
Calpurnia said, ‘Tom Robinson’s daddy sent you along this chicken this morning. I fixed it.’
‘You tell him I’m proud to get it – bet they don’t have chicken for breakfast at the White House. What are these?’
‘Rolls,’ said Calpurnia. ‘Estelle down at the hotel sent ‘em.’”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Fried Chicken and Rolls.
Book: To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee (1960).
Scene: “‘Gracious alive, Cal, what’s all this?’ He was staring at his breakfast plate.
Calpurnia said, ‘Tom Robinson’s daddy sent you along this chicken this morning. I fixed it.’
‘You tell him I’m proud to get it – bet they don’t have chicken for breakfast at the White House. What are these?’
‘Rolls,’ said Calpurnia. ‘Estelle down at the hotel sent ‘em.’”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Dumplings.
Book: The Kitchen God’s Wife by Amy Tan (1992).
Scene: “Back home, I told the cook girl to boil enough pots of water and to chop enough pork and vegetables to make a thousand dumplings, both steamed and boiled, with plenty of fresh ginger, good soy sauce, and sweet vinegar for dipping. Hulan helped me knead the flour and roll out the dough into small circles.
I admit I was at first impressed by her cooking skills.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Dumplings.
Book: The Kitchen God’s Wife by Amy Tan (1992).
Scene: “Back home, I told the cook girl to boil enough pots of water and to chop enough pork and vegetables to make a thousand dumplings, both steamed and boiled, with plenty of fresh ginger, good soy sauce, and sweet vinegar for dipping. Hulan helped me knead the flour and roll out the dough into small circles.
I admit I was at first impressed by her cooking skills.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Christmas Pudding.
Book: Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone by JK Rowling (1997).
Scene: “Flaming Christmas puddings followed the turkey. Percy nearly broke his teeth on a silver sickle embedded in his slice. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder and redder in the face as he called for more wine, finally kissing Professor McGonagall on the cheek, who, to Harry’s amazement, giggled and blushed, her top hat lopsided.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Christmas Pudding.
Book: Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone by JK Rowling (1997).
Scene: “Flaming Christmas puddings followed the turkey. Percy nearly broke his teeth on a silver sickle embedded in his slice. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder and redder in the face as he called for more wine, finally kissing Professor McGonagall on the cheek, who, to Harry’s amazement, giggled and blushed, her top hat lopsided.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Key Lime Pie.
Book: Heartburn by Nora Ephron (1983).
Scene: “If I had to do it all over again, I would have made a different pie. The pie I threw at Mark made a terrific mess, but a blueberry pie would have been even better, since it would have permanently ruined his new blazer, the one he bought with Thelma. But Betty said to bring a Key lime pie, so I did.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Key Lime Pie.
Book: Heartburn by Nora Ephron (1983).
Scene: “If I had to do it all over again, I would have made a different pie. The pie I threw at Mark made a terrific mess, but a blueberry pie would have been even better, since it would have permanently ruined his new blazer, the one he bought with Thelma. But Betty said to bring a Key lime pie, so I did.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Sticky Ginger Cake.
Book: Five on a Treasure Island by Enid Blyton (1942).
Scene: “It wasn’t long before all four were sitting down to a good tea. Aunt Fanny had baked new scones for them, and had made a ginger cake with black treacle. It was dark brown and sticky to eat. The children finished it all up and said it was the nicest they had ever tasted.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Sticky Ginger Cake.
Book: Five on a Treasure Island by Enid Blyton (1942).
Scene: “It wasn’t long before all four were sitting down to a good tea. Aunt Fanny had baked new scones for them, and had made a ginger cake with black treacle. It was dark brown and sticky to eat. The children finished it all up and said it was the nicest they had ever tasted.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Marmalade Roll.
Book: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis (1950)
Scene: “And when they had finished the fish, Mrs Beaver brought unexpectedly out of the oven a great and gloriously sticky marmalade roll, steaming hot, and at the same time moved the kettle onto the fire, so that when they had finished the marmalade roll the tea was made and ready to be poured out.”
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young
image.cleanCaption:
Meal: Marmalade Roll.
Book: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis (1950)
Scene: “And when they had finished the fish, Mrs Beaver brought unexpectedly out of the oven a great and gloriously sticky marmalade roll, steaming hot, and at the same time moved the kettle onto the fire, so that when they had finished the marmalade roll the tea was made and ready to be poured out.”
Recipe here.

image.caption:
Meal: Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight.
Book: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory by Roald Dahl (1964).
Scene: “‘Why not?’ the fat shopkeeper said, reaching behind him again and taking another Whipple-Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight from the shelf. He laid it on the counter. Charlie picked it up and tore off the wrapper … and suddenly … from underneath the wrapper … there came a brilliant flash of gold. Charlie’s heart stood still.’
Recipe here. Photograph: Kate Young

cards.title: Cassetteboy remix the news / Taylor Swift forces government U-turn on welfare spending
cards.rawTitle: Taylor Swift forces government U-turn on welfare spending

item.title: Cassetteboy remix the news: Taylor Swift forces government u-turn on welfare spending
item.trailText: Mashup artists Cassetteboy edit the last month's TV news coverage
item.standFirst: Mashup artists Cassetteboy edit the last month's TV news coverage, including the first Conservative budget in 20 years and its impact on the NHS; the financial crisis in the eurozone and how Greece is coping with record debt; the Confederate flag and its implications for the race debate in the US; Taylor Swift's influence on the prime minister; and Iain Duncan Smith's music career

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Cassetteboy Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for Cassetteboy

cards.title: Ant-Man trailer / Paul Rudd and Michael Douglas in Marvel's latest
cards.rawTitle: Paul Rudd and Michael Douglas in Marvel's latest

item.title: Ant-Man trailer: Paul Rudd and Michael Douglas in Marvel's latest
item.trailText: Watch the trailer for Ant-Man, Marvel's next superhero adventure, starring Paul Rudd as a con artist who gains a suit that allows him to shrink in size yet increase in strength. The film also stars Michael Douglas and Evangeline Lilly. It's due for release on 17 July in the UK and US
item.standFirst: Watch the trailer for Ant-Man, Marvel's next superhero adventure, starring Paul Rudd as a con artist who gains a suit that allows him to shrink in size yet increase in strength. The film also stars Michael Douglas and Evangeline Lilly. It's due for release on 17 July in the UK and US
